body:
is your LD_LIBRARY_PATH set properly so the cuda libs can be found?
https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/archive/10.1/cuda-installation-guide-linux/index.html#post-installation-actions

Yes I had added those in my bashrc as well. Still it gives same error upon reinstalling onnxruntime-gpu

I finally was able to fix it by using a hack.

I noticed that the file it couldn't find were present in cuda-10.2 folder.

`sudo cp /usr/local/cuda-10.2/targets/x86_64-linux/lib/libcublas.so.10 /usr/local/cuda-10.1/lib64/`

`sudo cp /usr/local/cuda-10.2/targets/x86_64-linux/lib/libcublasLt.so.10 /usr/local/cuda-10.1/lib64/`

Then I could import onnx


>>> import onnxruntime
>>> onnxruntime.get_device()
'GPU'

if i'm understanding correctly,
you previously installed both cuda 10.1 and 10.2 on your system?  but the cuda 10.1 installation dir was missing the shared libs?
Nvidia suddenly removed the cublas for CUDA 10.1.  You installed cublas 10.2 .

I used [this image](https://hub.docker.com/layers/nvidia/cuda/10.1-cudnn7-runtime-ubuntu16.04/images/sha256-66e68a811e326335c16401c4c551b37847b525a04ebf667f8473794f3e42ed6c?context=explore) and installed ORT in it and didn't find any issue. I don't have a 18.04 handy to try there.

root@221c18c41b09:/# lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 16.04.6 LTS
Release:        16.04
Codename:       xenial

root@221c18c41b09:/# pip list | grep onnxruntime
onnxruntime-gpu     1.4.0
You are using pip version 19.0.3, however version 20.2.2 is available.
You should consider upgrading via the 'pip install --upgrade pip' command.

root@221c18c41b09:/# python3 -c 'import onnxruntime as rt; print(rt.get_device())'
GPU
root@221c18c41b09:/#

After running apt-get update && apt-get upgrade, this stops working.

root@221c18c41b09:/# python3 -c 'import onnxruntime as rt; print(rt.get_device())'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/onnxruntime/__init__.py", line 13, in <module>
    from onnxruntime.capi._pybind_state import get_all_providers, get_available_providers, get_device, set_seed, \
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/onnxruntime/capi/_pybind_state.py", line 9, in <module>
    import onnxruntime.capi._ld_preload  # noqa: F401
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/onnxruntime/capi/_ld_preload.py", line 12, in <module>
    _libcublas = CDLL("libcublas.so.10", mode=RTLD_GLOBAL)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 364, in __init__
    self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)
OSError: libcublas.so.10: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
root@221c18c41b09:/#
Do we have any solution to this `OSError: libcublas.so.10` issue?
Hi @Exlsunshine Right now the solution would be to copy libcublas.so.10 and libcublasLt.so.10 from CUDA 10.2 like I mentioned.

the issue here is with doing any system upgrades which upgrades your libcublas10 version.
libcublas10 version 10.2.1.243-1 gets installed in /usr/local/cuda-10.1/lib64
if you update to version 10.2.2.214-1 it gets installed in /usr/local/cuda-10.2/lib64 , even if you never installed cuda 10.2
that is why onnxruntime cannot find the library (and @sayak1711's workaround of copying the libs to cuda-10.1 directory works)
per nvidia's guidance, another way is to hold libcublas10 to the old version using `apt-mark hold libcublas10` to prevent system upgrades from upgrading it.

> the issue here is with doing any system upgrades which upgrades your libcublas10 version.
> libcublas10 version 10.2.1.243-1 gets installed in /usr/local/cuda-10.1/lib64
> if you update to version 10.2.2.214-1 it gets installed in /usr/local/cuda-10.2/lib64 , even if you never installed cuda 10.2
> that is why onnxruntime cannot find the library (and @sayak1711's workaround of copying the libs to cuda-10.1 directory works)
> per nvidia's guidance, another way is to hold libcublas10 to the old version using `apt-mark hold libcublas10` to prevent system upgrades from upgrading it.

Thanks for the details, copying `.so` is no big deal, but do we have to do this manually all the time or just temporary?

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.

Trying to install onnxruntime-gpu into docker container nvcr.io/nvidia/tensorrt:20.09-py3 and have the same problem when importing onnxruntime.
`OSError: libcublas.so.10: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

Check for Cuda and cuDNN version
refer [link](https://www.onnxruntime.ai/docs/reference/execution-providers/CUDA-ExecutionProvider.html) for version understanding.
example: if you have Cuda 10.2 then you require cuDNN 8.0.3




> Trying to install onnxruntime-gpu into docker container nvcr.io/nvidia/tensorrt:20.09-py3 and have the same problem when importing onnxruntime.
> `OSError: libcublas.so.10: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

Thank god I got the solution, 
![WeeklyReport_TTS](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36092323/126825712-a3e42a50-d2c1-4b80-af09-adfbe34236c3.png)

For whom work with docker deployment
```
FROM nvidia/cuda:10.2-cudnn8-runtime-ubuntu18.04

COPY . /

RUN apt-get update && apt-get install --no-install-recommends --no-install-suggests -y curl
RUN apt-get -y install python3.7
RUN apt-get -y install python3-pip
```
